comments.commentBody: I would say, in this case -- if we were smart enough to figure out a way of taking out this entire regime and all its missile systems in one fell swoop -- about 4 billion people would hang the Stars and Stripes that same day.

I'm generally against intervention.  I was against invading Iraq for instance.  I believe in each nation the people themselves should determine what happens.  That said - North Korea is a threat to everyone and needs to be dealt with.  Any attempt to take down this regime without China's help could explode - literally and figuratively.  Seoul could indeed be bombarded by Kim's weapons.  That would be ugly.  China has grown tired of dealing with this maniac as well.  Trump should make a deal with China...  US troops will leave the Korean peninsula if they get rid of Kim and de-militarize the border with the South.

This goes all the way to the Truman era. Getting involved with North Korea demanded the approval of the U.N.
Truman constantly sent orders to Gen. MacArthur under cover and direction of the U.N.. Truman believed unilateral action would put the US in a terrible position, only to bring in China and the Soviets. However, these two allies into of ROK came into the war regardless of Truman's policies. So, where are we today? Trump has no options. The US can go it alone when feeling threatened by the ROK. The U.N.would surely be blocked by the veto powers of China and Russia, both permanent members of the security council.
ROK is an economic drain on both Russia and China. The Soviets said adios to Cuba for the same reason. However, the distance of Cuba from Russia is greatly different than the ROK from both communist giants and that is the biggest factor. A nuclear attack, with today's weapons, poses contamination of those two communist powers, which would cause retaliation. Not a pretty picture.

a lot of terminal naives are writing here. they suggest diplomacy, even though diplomacy has allowed the North koreans to gain > 25 years time. Obama's supposed intelligence didn't achieve anything. Only extreme threats of military force, or more likely, actual use of military force, will cause the Kim dynasty to climb down. Trump's strong diplomacy has forced China to stop buy coal from N. Korea, which is enough to cause a severe economic crisis there.  > 25 years of soft diplomacy didn't achieve that. I am inviting dems to stop helping enemies as a way to weaken Trump

Assuming this article is accurate, we have already meddled with a foreign nation's nuclear and missile programs. I would assume they will meddle with ours.

That said, actually blowing up their missile--on the pad--is just a step too far. But, it seems to me China should be assured that IF N Korea uses a missile to attack another country, China will be held responsible. No nuance is necessary to deliver that message.
This is a terrible time to have foreign policy by Twitter and a US president who is creating so many enemies, domestic and foreign, he is as vulnerable is Kim and would, like Kim, benefit from war.

Kurt, your comment sounds like a capsule summary of Scott Walker's op-ed:

"Ignore facts and hope nobody notices."

Unfortunately for Gov Walker, almost all the commenters noted that starting at approximately the same place, the liberal government of Minnesota far surpassed the conservative government of Wisconsin.

Similarly, you portray Obama as doing nothing for 8 years but "yapping" (and following what I can only assume is your faux-news inspired reading, choosing "global warming" rather than "climate change") and somehow missed the first paragraph of this article.

It's salutary to read such comments, and ponder how it might be possible to have a reasonable conversation with people who get their information in alternate, fact-free universes.

www.remember-to-breathe.org

The first 100 days or the first 100 pages of a sci-fi novel? Two unstable leaders, weirdly loyal followers (pics of colorful humans in subordination to missiles), rouge Russian scientists, an isolated and almost alien nation, and world-destroying nuclear weapons. Early in chapter one, one leader TWEETS a dare to the other? There is only one place the book would go.

This is the worst news yet of the Trump presidency.

for every nuke and missile North Korea has that can reach the US, Taiwan gets a package of ten that can reach all of China, ten nuke subs. Japan, five. The dali lama, two. Vietnam, one. Singapore deserves a few as well.

China thinks nuclear non proliferation is free except for North Korea. why it thinks that Except for its reliance on the Pax Americana I do not know. But for China North Korea would have no nukes. N. Korea has a population of 25 million, Taiwan 23, Tibet 3 million, Vietnam 90 million.China invaded Vietnam in 1979.

There is a law of foreign policy. If the sauce is good for the goose it is good for the gander. The idea the US is helpless because options are imperfect is a delusional idea.

you indeed failed to realize it was with our moral support China invaded Vietnam in 1979.  1) we were still seething we couldn't beat the North... 2) China wasn't getting along with the Soviets and we sought to play them off each other.

Andre

In the fail to realize department,

The US is not the cause of Chinese invasions of (north) Vietnam, "moral support" (!) or not.

Unless China is our imperial puppet. me, I think China pursues its interests according to its current dictators' iffy grasp of those interests.

Does the blame America but give no credit thingie so popular on the apology tour have a limit? I have yet to see it. Trump enablers all.
One cannot logically compare Global Warming and Kim Jong-un's nuclear capabilities; that is, unless the "warming" is from the aftermath of North Korean nuclear weapons.

That strike would mean the end of south korea. Don't you think we would have done that already, otherwise? Sheesh....

The only solution is actually to take a very very large financial hit and basically pay China to resolve the NK issue. I'm talking giving them a trillion dollars or something on that order. They are afraid that if they let the NK situation deteriorate, they will need to subsidize the people of NK for years. We pay them to do it, and they might do it. It's literally the only way to avoid a massive massive death count.

"For years, the Pentagon’s most senior officers and officials have publicly advocated these kinds of sophisticated attacks in little-noticed testimony to Congress and at defense conferences."
It's funny how all this stuff passed unnoticed for eight years. Now that President Obama is no longer president, New York Times wants to instill fear and uncertainty in its readers. We live in a dangerous world, but it's as if the US (or at least New York Times readers) took a break from reality for eight years.
Maybe this is the only way for employees to get information to their boss.

Since the breakup of the USSR I have always felt North Korea would be the epicenter of World War III. All it would take would be equally unstable leaders on both sides. And look at what we have here. May it be quick.

The thought that this article is meant as a briefing for the Donald keeps running thru my head. I've read it twice; besides being wonderful journalism, it feels like national security personnel are trying to inform a reader who is the president.
Thanks, NYT. Another very specific reason for my high blood pressure.

The question here is... if we can't stop an extremely hostile foreign power that can't hit us hard at present, why is our actual military strength/will. It is time to take this regime out with a fast, preemptive strike and a backroom d al with China that they can select the new govt. enough is enough.

More and more we are learning that Reagan's Star Wars budget buster spending went almost nowhere. This kind of bizarre spending is about to return again with Trump.

Meanwhile, what do we have to show? I fear for our troops, who seem to be sitting ducks at the DMZ. We've always relied on NK being rational enough not to attack our troops because it would bring obliteration to NK. But now, with lunatics leading all three nations, I'm not so sure.

Trump says “It won’t happen!” As always, he has no rational plan to back up his big talk.

(North Korean president with emotional maturity of a 10-yr old advancing nuclear weapon capability) (American president with emotional maturity of a 10-yr old bad Twitter bullying habit sophisticated nuclear weapons program) = New-Age Cold War.

How unbelievably unfair of us baby boomer grown-ups to saddle yet another generation of children with the fear of a nuclear holocaust. To quote our president: SAD!

Re: to commenters suggesting Mr. Trump did indeed 'inherit a mess.' Did it never occur to Mr. Trump when he was seeking office that global management, even if only as regards our interests, was perhaps a bit more complicated than his campaign slogans would suggest and that diplomacy does serve a purpose?

Yup... it's the new New Frontier.

But only makes sense to some primitive swamp animals who live in a command bunker in Washington far from North Korea, Mexico, Iran and other threatening European countries, and are mostly concerned with attacking on all imaginary domestic fronts at once.

We need a bit more imagination from The Leader. Can't he move the swamp to the Rio Grande or drain the wall or something?

Beijing is about 500 miles from Pyongyang; withing the range of a nuclear equipped SCUD missile right now. Whatever fears we have China has in spades. Which is why they are so very careful of how they handle North Korea.

Any missile attack against the US would have to overfly Russia also. Another player whose technology has given North Korea the ability to act.

Cyber war has, apparently, helped us, but cyber attacks must continually evolve because the North Koreans can buy the expertise to overcome the last ones used.

Bu hey, let's "Make America Great Again" by upending NATO, China, Russia and the rest of the entire world because the only thing that counts is "America First," and everyone else can just shove it.

Kudos to the NYT for putting this substantive report as their lead article, and shunting Trump's latest attempt at deflection ("Obama hacks Trump Tower!") to a secondary position, which it doesn't even deserve.

The fact-based media must continue to resist the lure of Trump's attempt to cheapen their brand and turn their publications into the supermarket checkout rags.
What's most frightening for me is seeing Trump's name mentioned in the same sentence with the words "national intelligence."

Given what we've seen so far from Donald Trump's mindset, it's his that Americans should be worrying about , and not Kim Jong-un's.
And given Mr. Trump's repeated absences from National Security meetings, and a itchy, thin-skinned finger on the Nuclear Codes, any problems with North Korea may be over before they've actually begun.

The technical problems have all been worked out. The political problems can be explained by the weapons industry. How do you explain some of the "absurd" things they have done like shelling military insignificant fishing villages. Keep spending for weapons to win WWII. Kim is being bribed to churn.
